title: Ibrahim Kargbo
text:
Ibrahim Obreh Kargbo (born 10 April 1969) is a <a href="Sierra%20Leone">Sierra Leone</a>an former <a href="soccer">football</a> player. He ended his career with a suspension over match-fixing.
Career.
Former teams are <a href="Old%20Edwardians%20F.C.">Old Edwardians F.C.</a>, <a href="Feyenoord%20Rotterdam">Feyenoord Rotterdam</a>, <a href="Racing%20White%20Daring">RWD Molenbeek</a>, <a href="Sporting%20Charleroi">Sporting Charleroi</a>, <a href="Malatyaspor">Malatyaspor</a>, <a href="RWDM%20Brussels%20FC">FC Brussels</a> and <a href="Willem%20II%20Tilburg">Willem II</a>. During his time at <a href="Willem%20II%20Tilburg">Willem II</a> he was a key player. He played more than 100 matches for the Dutch side and then moved to <a href="FC%20Baku">FC Baku</a> when his contract had expired. In August 2013, he joined his former team Brussels but decided to terminate his contract a month later.
On 11 July 2014, Kargbo went on trial with <a href="Swindon%20Town%20F.C.">Swindon Town</a> along with Elikem Amenku after his release from <a href="West%20Bromwich%20Albion%20F.C.">West Bromwich Albion</a>, although he did not sign for the club. Instead, Kargbo signed for <a href="Atl%C3%A9tico%20Clube%20de%20Portugal">Atlético</a>. He later played for <a href="Barkingside%20F.C.">Barkingside</a> and <a href="Thamesmead%20Town%20F.C.">Thamesmead Town</a>, before signing for <a href="Welling%20United%20F.C.">Welling United</a> in February 2016.
After making 10 appearances for Welling in their unsuccessful attempt to stay in the National League, Kargbo signed for <a href="Dulwich%20Hamlet%20F.C.">Dulwich Hamlet</a> of the <a href="Isthmian%20League">Isthmian League</a> Premier Division ahead of the 2016−17 season, going on to make 45 appearances and scoring 3 goals in all competitions in his first season at the club.
Position.
He plays as a <a href="Defender%20%28football%29">defender</a> or <a href="Midfielder%20%28association%20football%29%23Defensive%20midfielder">Defensive Midfielder</a>.
International career.
Kargbo is first choice defender for the <a href="Sierra%20Leone%20national%20football%20team">Sierra Leone national football team</a> and he succeeded <a href="Mohamed%20Kallon">Mohamed Kallon</a> as the Leone Stars' national team captain.
Legal trouble.
In July 2014, Kargbo was among 15 players and officials suspended from international football, along with <a href="Ibrahim%20Koroma">Ibrahim Koroma</a>, <a href="Samuel%20Barlay">Samuel Barlay</a> and <a href="Christian%20Caulker">Christian Caulker</a> over allegations of <a href="Match%20fixing%20in%20association%20football">match-fixing</a> relating to an <a href="Africa%20Cup%20of%20Nations">Africa Cup of Nations</a> qualifier in 2008 against <a href="South%20Africa%20national%20football%20team">South Africa</a> which ended <a href="2010%20FIFA%20World%20Cup%20qualification%20%E2%80%93%20CAF%20Second%20Round%23South%20Africa%20v%20Sierra%20Leone">0–0</a>.
Allegedly, he was also involved in match fixing during his time at Willem II, serving as the main contact for a gambling syndicate and selling them losses against <a href="AFC%20Ajax">AFC Ajax</a> and Feyenoord; Kargbo has denied the allegations. His ban was lifted in 2015.
On 15 February 2016, however, the <a href="Royal%20Dutch%20Football%20Association">Royal Dutch Football Association</a> reported it had found evidence of Kargbo being actively involved in match fixing, specifically in a match against FC Utrecht on 9 August 2009 (which Willem II lost 1–0). Kargbo is now banned from playing football in the Netherlands.
In April 2019, <a href="FIFA">FIFA</a> banned Kargbo for life from all footballing activities due to <a href="Match%20fixing%20in%20association%20football">"match manipulation"</a>.
Personal life.
His son <a href="Ibrahim%20Kargbo%20Jr.">Ibrahim Kargbo Jr.</a> is also a footballer.
